A group of investigators is planning a study that would evaluate that association, taking into account a set of potential confounders. Which could be the null hypothesis for the study?

Options:
  High plasma CRP level carries increased risk of acute coronary syndromes
  High plasma CRP level is related to the occurrence of acute coronary syndromes
✓ High plasma CRP level has no association with acute coronary syndrome
  Acute coronary syndrome can be predicted by high plasma CRP
  High plasma CRP level can cause acute coronary syndromes

Explanation:
The Null Hypothesis (H0) always assumes that there is NO relationship, association, or difference between the variables being studied.

================================================================================
Question 869 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A person involved in a road traffic accident has a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 200 mg/ 100 ml. What is the expected clinical sign at this level?

Options:
  No noticeable effect
  Slight euphoria
✓ Slurred speech and incoordination
  Coma
  Death

Explanation:
A BAC of 200 mg/dL (0.2%) typically results in moderate to severe intoxication characterized by ataxia, slurred speech, confusion, and incoordination. Coma usually occurs at higher levels (>300 mg/dL).

================================================================================
Question 870 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 69-year old man has had a 9kg weight loss, proximal muscle weakness and difficulty with urination for the past 5 months. On physical examination, he has 4/5 muscle strength in his proximal extremities that does not diminish with repetitive motion. He has no muscle pain or loss of mobility. Laboratory studies show that he does not have serum antibodies to acetylcholine receptor. He was prescribed anticholinesterase agents but shows no improvement. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely to be present in this man?

Options:
  Chronic hepatitis C
  Diabetes mellitus
  Duchenne muscular dystrophy
  Lead poisoning
✓ Small cell lung carcinoma

Explanation:
This patient has Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS), indicated by proximal weakness, autonomic dysfunction (urination difficulty), and lack of response to anticholinesterases/negative AChR antibodies. LEMS is a paraneoplastic syndrome strongly associated with Small Cell Lung Carcinoma.

================================================================================
Question 871 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45 year Old male businessman attends your clinic, complaining Of excessive worries, problems concentrating, irritability, dizzy spells, choking sensation, episodic shakes, sweats and at times his mind going blank. He admits to having some work related stress recently, but describes himself as a worrier by nature. What would be your most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Agoraphobia
✓ Generalized anxiety disorder
  Obsessive compulsive disorder
  Panic attacks
  Post traumatic stress disorder

Explanation:
Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) is characterized by excessive, difficult-to-control worry occurring for at least 6 months, accompanied by somatic symptoms like restlessness, fatigue, concentration problems, and irritability. The patient's description as a "worrier by nature" supports this.

================================================================================
Question 872 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 27-year-old male complained to his physician Of feeling "real slow" and of a bilateral hand tremor that improved when he picked up his coffee cup. The man, suffering from paranoid schizophrenia, was currently treated in an outpatient program. Physical examination showed cogwheel rigidity in both arms, stooped posture, and a shuffling gait. Which of the following drugs most likely caused these adverse effects?

Options:
  Clozapine
✓ Haloperidol
  Metoclopramide
  Olanzapine
  Aripiprazole

Explanation:
Haloperidol is a typical (first-generation) antipsychotic with high D2 receptor affinity. It is well-known for causing Extrapyramidal Symptoms (EPS) such as drug-induced Parkinsonism (rigidity, bradykinesia, tremor).

================================================================================
Question 873 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue and drooping eyelids that worsen throughout the day. She has difficulty chewing and swallowing by evening. Physical examination reveals bilateral ptosis and weakness of extraocular muscles, but normal deep tendon reflexes and sensation. Which of the following is the best initial diagnostic test for this patient?

Options:
  CT scan of the chest
  Edrophonium (Tensilon) test
  Repetitive nerve stimulation test
✓ Serum anti-acetylcholine receptor antibody test
  Single-fiber electromyography

Explanation:
Testing for Serum Anti-Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) antibodies is the most specific initial test for confirming a diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis.

================================================================================
Question 874 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A dead body brought to mortuary with suspicion of heroin intoxication. Name the ideal sample for chemical analysis:

Options:
  Heart and lungs
  Kidney
  Liver and spleen
  Small intestines with contents
✓ Stomach with contents

Explanation:
In general forensic toxicology for suspected fatal intoxication/poisoning, 'Stomach with contents' is the standard ideal sample to identify ingested substances. While heroin is often injected (making liver/bile/urine useful), stomach contents remain a primary forensic sample answer for general 'intoxication' questions unless IV route is specified as the exclusive route.

================================================================================
Question 875 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
a 12 year old girl comes to you in OPD with complaints of being lost sometimes. she is having this issue for the last 1 month. even her school teacher complaints that she sometimes stares with no response but then quickly gets normal. there is no loss of consciousness, no behavorial problems. her school performance is well. previously was a normal child. you order a baseline EEG for the child and it shows a typical pattern of epilepsy. you councel the mother and start her on antiepileptic medication. what is the type of seizure in this child.

Options:
✓ absence seizures
  generalized tonic clonic epilepsy
  focal seizures
  subtle seizures
  Ionic seizures

Explanation:
The clinical picture of brief staring spells with loss of awareness, no convulsions, and rapid return to baseline (without post-ictal confusion) in a child is classic for Childhood Absence Epilepsy.

================================================================================
Question 876 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 72-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease and diabetes mellitus suddenly collapses at home. Paramedics find her in cardiac arrest, and she is successfully resuscitated after 10 minutes. However, she remains unresponsive. MRI of the brain shows bilateral necrosis of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her neurological injury?

Options:
  Brain abscess
  Focal ischemia due to embolism
  Hypertensive hemorrhage
✓ Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy
  Subdural hematoma

Explanation:
The CA1 region of the hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most vulnerable areas of the brain to global ischemia (hypoxia). Selective necrosis in these areas after cardiac arrest is diagnostic of Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy.

================================================================================
Question 877 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A disorder characterized by withdrawal from reality and living in a world of fantasy with presence of delusions and hallucinations is known as

Options:
  Neurosis
✓ Psychosis
  Stupor
  Delirium
  Dementia

Explanation:
Psychosis is defined as a loss of contact with reality, typically manifesting as delusions (false beliefs) and hallucinations (false sensory perceptions).

================================================================================
Question 878 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A group of investigators are studying the relationship between a particular 5-lipoxygenase genotype and atherosclerosis. A study population is randomly selected. Blood samples are obtained for leukocyte genotyping, and ultrasonography is performed to assess carotid intima-media thickness, a marker of atherosclerosis. It is concluded that the particular 5-lipoxygenase genotype is associated with a predisposition to atherosclerosis. Identify the study design used by the investigators

Options:
  Randomized Clinical Trial
✓ Cross-Sectional Study
  Case-Control Study
  Cohort Study
  Case Series Report

Explanation:
The study assesses both the exposure (genotype) and the outcome (atherosclerosis/intima-media thickness) at the same time in a randomly selected population. This is a Cross-Sectional study.

================================================================================
Question 879 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 24-year-old female with a long history of absence seizures had been successfully managed with valproic acid for the past 5 years. The patient had recently married, and during her last office visit she expressed the desire to start a family. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this patient to substitute for valproic acid therapy?

Options:
  Carbamazepine
  Clonazepam
  Phenytoin
✓ Ethosuximide
  Tiagabine

Explanation:
Valproic acid is teratogenic. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for Absence Seizures and has a better safety profile for pregnancy compared to Valproate. (Lamotrigine is another option often considered, but Ethosuximide is the specific narrow-spectrum agent for Absence).

================================================================================
Question 880 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30-year-old man presents with partial loss of vision, loss of balance and dizziness. The patient's mother had similar clinical symptoms. MRI shows bilateral cerebral atrophy and enlargement of the lateral ventricles. Which of the following gene abnormalities would be expected in the patient

Options:
  Deletion of an exon in the gene for presenilin
  Frame shift mutation in superoxide dismutase gene
✓ Expansion of a trinucleotide repeat
  Translocation of chromosome 21
  Point mutation in the gene for the prion protein

Explanation:
The symptoms (neurodegenerative) and imaging (ventricular enlargement due to caudate atrophy) combined with an autosomal dominant family history (mother) are strongly suggestive of Huntington's Disease (or potentially Spinocerebellar Ataxia), which are caused by Trinucleotide Repeat Expansions.

================================================================================
Question 881 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 56-year-old person presents with chronic neuropathic pain that has been persistent for the past six months. Despite physical therapy and over-the-counter analgesics, the pain continues to interfere with daily activities. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for adjunctive treatment of this patient's chronic pain?

Options:
  Cox-II inhibitors
  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  Opioids
  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors
✓ Tricyclic antidepressants

Explanation:
Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs), such as Amitriptyline, are first-line adjunctive agents for the management of chronic neuropathic pain.

================================================================================
Question 882 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A group of investigators describes a linear association between calcium content of the aortic valve cusps as measured in vivo and the diameter of the aortic opening. They report a correlation coefficient of -0.45 and a p value of 0.001. Which could be the best interpretation of the results reported by the investigators?

Options:
  Alpha-error level is set too low
  Sample size is too low for drawing definite conclusions
  Calcium deposition causes narrowing of the aortic valve opening
✓ As calcium content of the cusps increases the aortic valve diameter decreases
  As aortic valve diameter decreases the calcium content of the cusps decreases

Explanation:
A negative correlation coefficient (-0.45) indicates an inverse relationship: as one variable increases (Calcium content), the other variable decreases (Aortic valve diameter).

================================================================================
Question 883 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A cohort study is conducted to assess the relationship between a high-fat diet and colorectal adenocarcinoma. The study shows that no association exists between the exposure and the outcome after controlling for known risk factors (age, fiber consumption, and family history of cancer): relative risk - 1.35 (p 0.25). The investigators also report that 40% of the subjects in the high-fat group and 36% of those in the low-fat group were lost to follow-up. Based on this information, which bias is most likely to be present?

Options:
  Confounding
  Recall bias
  Ascertainment bias
✓ Selection bias
  Observer bias

Explanation:
High rates of loss to follow-up (attrition), especially if different between groups, result in Selection Bias.

================================================================================
Question 884 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
Wernicke's encephalopathy is observed in chronic poisoning caused by:

Options:
✓ Alcohol
  Cannabis
  Cocaine
  Lead
  Mercury

Explanation:
Wernicke's encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, which is most commonly seen in chronic Alcoholism.

================================================================================
Question 885 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 65-year-old man was prescribed an antidepressant that has caused him feeling uncomfortable as he is having drowsiness, dry mouth, palpitations and urinary retention. Which drug was most likely prescribed to this patient?

Options:
  Citalopram
  Alprazolam
✓ Amitriptyline
  Fluoxetine
  Duloxetine

Explanation:
These are classic anticholinergic side effects (dry mouth, urinary retention, palpitations/tachycardia) associated with Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs) like Amitriptyline.

================================================================================
Question 886 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A habitual alcoholic suddenly stops drinking and develops tremors, hallucinations, and seizures after 24 hours. This condition is known as:

Options:
  Alcoholic psychosis
  Korsakoff's psychosis
✓ Delirium tremens
  Alcoholic paranoia
  Alcoholic neuropathy

Explanation:
The progression from cessation of alcohol to tremors, seizures, and autonomic instability/hallucinations characterizes Delirium Tremens (though 'Alcoholic Psychosis' is a broader term, DTs is the specific acute withdrawal syndrome described).

================================================================================
Question 887 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
You see a middle-aged lady in your clinic who is very loud on presentation. She is wearing a very bright shade of lipstick and is dressed in bright mismatched clothes. She is restless and difficult to interrupt. She denies any problems and in fact "in the best state I have ever been". She appears to be quite grandiose in her statements during the review. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Acute confusional state
  Acute stress reaction
✓ Bipolar disorder current episode - manic
  Bipolar disorder current episode - hypomanic
  Paranoid schizophrenia

Explanation:
The patient exhibits classic symptoms of Mania: Grandiosity, elevated mood ("best state"), pressured speech (difficult to interrupt), increased energy/restlessness, and flamboyant appearance. This points to a Bipolar Disorder Manic Episode.

================================================================================
Question 888 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 30-year-old woman is found unconscious, with slow shallow breathing, pinpoint pupils, and no smell of alcohol. Empty blister packs of sleeping pills are nearby. Most probable diagnosis is:

Options:
  Alcohol intoxication
  Barbiturate poisoning
✓ Opium poisoning
  Chloral hydrate poisoning
  Benzodiazepine overdose

Explanation:
The classic triad of Opioid (Opium) overdose is: Coma (unconscious), Respiratory Depression (slow shallow breathing), and Pinpoint Pupils (miosis).

================================================================================
Question 889 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is the least likely cause of pregnancy related deaths in US(1998-- 2005)?

Options:
✓ General Anesthesia (failed intubation or aspiration)
  Haemorrhage
  Thrombotic Pulmonary Embolism
  Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.
  intra- uterine death.

Explanation:
Due to advancements in monitoring and airway management, anesthesia-related maternal mortality has decreased significantly and is less common compared to hemorrhage, embolism, and hypertension.

================================================================================
Question 890 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 34-year-old person with a known history of epilepsy presents to the emergency department with an episode of status epilepticus. The seizure has been ongoing despite treatment with repeated doses of lorazepam. The patient is currently not responding to verbal stimuli, and the seizure activity persists. The doctor on duty decides to administer a second line drug to manage his status epilepticus. What is the mechanism of action of the drug?

Options:
  Inhibits GABA uptake into the presynaptic neuron
✓ Stabilization of voltage-gated sodium channels
  Blockage Of T-type calcium channel
  Blockage of the synaptic vesicles proteins
  Inhibiting acetylcholinesterase

Explanation:
The standard second-line agent for benzodiazepine-refractory status epilepticus is Phenytoin (or Fosphenytoin). Phenytoin works by blocking/stabilizing voltage-gated sodium channels.

================================================================================
Question 891 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 75 year old woman presents with chronic severe headache, weight loss, anemia, and aching shoulders. Which test should be performed first?

Options:
✓ Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  Thyroid-stimulating hormone
  Liver function tests
  Reticulocyte count
  MRI brain

Explanation:
The clinical picture suggests Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis) associated with Polymyalgia Rheumatica (aching shoulders). The most appropriate screening test is the Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR), which is typically markedly elevated.

================================================================================
Question 892 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A man with no psychiatric illness kills another in a sudden rage after provocation. Which of the following defenses may reduce his punishment?

Options:
  Insanity
  Diminished responsibility
  Temporary insanity
✓ Provocation
  Automatism

Explanation:
In legal terms, 'Provocation' is a defense that can reduce a charge (e.g., from murder to manslaughter) if the act was done in a sudden heat of passion caused by provocation that would cause a reasonable person to lose self-control.

================================================================================
Question 893 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of progressive memory loss and disorientation. The pupils are small but react normally to light. Muscle tone is normal. A lumbar puncture returns clear, colorless CSF under normalpressure. An electroencephalogram shows diffuse slowing. A CT scan of the brain reveals moderate atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Alzheimer disease
  Multiple sclerosis
  Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  Huntington disease
  Parkinson's Disease

Explanation:
The presentation of progressive memory loss in an elderly patient with cerebral atrophy on CT and non-specific EEG slowing is most consistent with Alzheimer's Disease.

================================================================================
Question 894 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
Systematic desensitization is quite a popular form of psychological therapy. It's a gradual process that involves exposing an individual to a stressful stimulus in a step-wise manner but coupling it with relaxation therapy, and charting the resultant anxiety through the process. It is part of the management in which of the following anxiety disorders?

Options:
  Acute stress reaction
  Adjustment disorder
✓ Agoraphobia
  Generalized anxiety disorder
  Obsessive compulsive disorder

Explanation:
Systematic desensitization is primarily used for Phobic disorders, including Agoraphobia and specific phobias.

================================================================================
Question 895 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 48-year-old male alcoholic complained of flushing, nausea, a throbbing headache, and confusion after drinking a glass of wine. The man was taking a drug as part of his rehabilitation treatment for alcoholism. The symptoms of the patient are most likely caused by the accumulation in the body of which of the following substances?

Options:
✓ Acetaldehyde
  Dopamine
  Ethanol
  Formaldehyde
  Methanol

Explanation:
The patient is likely taking Disulfiram, which inhibits Acetaldehyde Dehydrogenase. This leads to the accumulation of Acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed, causing the unpleasant symptoms described.

================================================================================
Question 896 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 54-year-old woman complained to her physician of difficulty in falling asleep. She denied nocturnal insomnia or early awaking. The doctor prescribed ramelteon, one tablet at bedtime. Which of the following molecular actions most likely mediated the therapeutic e effect of the drug?

Options:
  Activation of GABA B receptors
  Blockade of al receptors
✓ Activation of melatonin receptors
  Blockade of glutamate receptors
  Activation of serotonin 5-HT3 receptors

Explanation:
Ramelteon is a Melatonin receptor agonist (MT1 and MT2 receptors) used to treat insomnia.

================================================================================
Question 897 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A physical examination was used to screen for breast cancer in 2,500 women with biopsy-proven cancer of the breast and in 5,000 without breast cancer. The results of the physical examination were positive (i.e., a mass was palpated) in 1,800 cases and in 800 control women, all of whom showed no evidence of cancer at biopsy. Calculate sensitivity:

Options:
  52%
✓ 72%
  82%
  92%
  62%

Explanation:
Sensitivity = True Positives / (True Positives + False Negatives) [Total with Disease]. Total with Disease = 2500. True Positives (Tested positive) = 1800. Sensitivity = 1800 / 2500 = 0.72 or 72%.

================================================================================
Question 898 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
An 88-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease dies of congestive heart failure. Examination of the brain at autopsy shows bilateral atrophy of the gyri, particularly in the frontal and hippocampal cortex. What additional finding might be expected in the brain of this patient?

Options:
  Cerebritis
✓ Hydrocephalus
  Lissencephaly
  Pachygyria
  patches of demyelination

Explanation:
Severe cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer's disease leads to compensatory enlargement of the ventricles to fill the space, a condition known as Hydrocephalus Ex Vacuo.

================================================================================
Question 899 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 70-year-old woman was undergoing cystoscopy for a suspected papilloma of the bladder. Before the procedure, the anesthesiologist administered alprazolam to induce conscious sedation and to avoid situational anxiety. When the cystoscopy was over, flumazenil was administered. Which of the following terms best defines the mode of act ion of this drug?

Options:
  Full agonist
  Functional antagonist
  Partial agonist
  Inverse agonist
✓ Competitive antagonist

Explanation:
Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the Benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor.

================================================================================
Question 900 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 23-year-old college student presents with euphoria, talkativeness, red eyes, and increased appetite after attending a party. Which drug is most likely responsible?

Options:
  Cocaine
✓ Cannabis
  Datura
  LSD
  Alcohol

Explanation:
This constellation of symptoms (Euphoria, Conjunctival injection/Red eyes, and Increased appetite/"Munchies") is pathognomonic for Cannabis intoxication.

================================================================================
Question 901 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 10 year boy presents with episodes of unsteadiness, double vision, and dysarthria. These are typically followed by headache. Computed tomography (CT) of the head and the results of laboratory studies are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

Options:
  Abdominal migraine
  Benign paroxysmal vertigo
  Exploding head syndrome
✓ Migraine with brainstem aura
  Intracranial hypertension

Explanation:
Migraine with brainstem aura (formerly Basilar Migraine) presents with brainstem symptoms like vertigo, diplopia, dysarthria, and ataxia, followed by a migraine headache, typically in young patients.

================================================================================
Question 902 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital for reduction of a dislocated shoulder. Sedation with diazepam was supplemented with a 30% concentration of nitrous oxide. Which of the following effects most likely occurred after nitrous oxide administration?

Options:
  Excellent skeletal muscle relaxation
  Profound respiratory depression
  Rapidly achieved unconsciousness
  Sharp decrease in blood pressure
✓ Very pronounced analgesia

Explanation:
Nitrous Oxide is known for providing significant analgesia (pain relief) even at sub-anesthetic concentrations, without causing profound respiratory depression or muscle relaxation.

================================================================================
Question 903 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
Officials at a large community hospital report an increased incidence of acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) among children aged 5-12. They point out that some households in the community are exposed to chemical waste from a nearby factory. They believe that chemical waste causes leukemia. If a study is designed to evaluate the hospital officials' claim, which subjects are most likely to comprise the control group?

Options:
  Children exposed to the chemical waste who do not suffer from ALL
  Children not exposed to the chemical waste who do not suffer from ALL
✓ Children from the outpatient clinic who do not suffer from ALL
  Children not exposed to the chemical waste who suffer from ALL
  Children who suffered from ALL but got cured

Explanation:
In a case-control study (starting with ALL cases), controls should represent the population from which the cases arose but without the disease. Hospital-based controls (children from the outpatient clinic without ALL) are often used to reduce selection bias associated with healthcare access, provided they don't have diseases related to the exposure.

================================================================================
Question 904 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
a 7 year old child comes to ER with 1 month history of fever on and off associated with seizures, vomiting and weight loss. the child was admitted for the same complaint a week back, was given broad spectrum antibiotics and discharged. parents complaint that the child has detoriated now and is deeply comatose with decorticate posturing and abnormal breathing pattern.you advise urgent admission to ICU and commencement Of antituberculous treatment. what is the stage of TBM in the child

Options:
  stage 1
  stage 2
✓ stage 3
  stage 4
  stage 5

Explanation:
Tuberculous Meningitis Stage 3 (BMRC staging) is characterized by severe neurological impairment, including coma, stupor, and severe irregular breathing or posturing.

================================================================================
Question 905 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old person with a history of alcohol dependence is prescribed an antibiotic for a bacterial infection. Shortly after taking the antibiotic, he experiences symptoms including severe headache, flushing, nausea, vomiting, and palpitations. Which of the following antibiotics is most likely responsible for the observed reaction?

Options:
  Amikacin
  Amoxicillin
✓ Cefotetan
  Clarithromycin
  Moxifloxacin

Explanation:
Cefotetan (and Cefoperazone) has an N-methylthiotetrazole (NMTT) side chain that inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, causing a Disulfiram-like reaction when alcohol is consumed.

================================================================================
Question 906 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 68-year-old woman presents to the clinic with her daughter, who is concerned about her mother's memory. The patient has been forgetting recent events, frequently repeats herself in conversations, and has trouble recalling the names of familiar people. She has no significant past medical history, except for hypertension, which is well controlled. The cognitive changes have gradually worsened over the last year. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ Alzheimer's disease
  Frontotemporal dementia
  Normal aging
  Parkinson's disease
  Vascular Dementia

Explanation:
The gradual, progressive loss of short-term memory (forgetting recent events) in an elderly patient is the hallmark presentation of Alzheimer's Disease. Normal aging typically involves slower processing but preserved function.

================================================================================
Question 907 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A group of investigators conducts a study to evaluate the association between serum homocysteine level and the risk Of myocardial infarction. They conclude that a high baseline plasma homocysteine level is associated With an increased risk of myocardial infarction and report a risk ratio (RR) of 1.08 and a p value of 0.01. What is the most accurate statement about the results of the study?

Options:
✓ There is an 8% chance that increased homocysteine levels cause myocardial infarction
  There is a 1% probability that there is no association
  The 95% confidence interval for the RR includes 1.0
  The study has insufficient power to reach a definite conclusion
  There is a 10% probability that the association is underestimated

Explanation:
This question requires interpretation of RR and P. A p-value of 0.01 indicates statistical significance (chance of random finding is 1%). RR of 1.08 indicates an 8% increase in risk. While option A is phrased casually ('chance that... causes'), it is the intended interpretation of the Risk Ratio (1.08 = 8% excess risk) in the context of the exam options. (Strictly, p-value relates to the probability of the data given the null hypothesis, but option A describes the Risk Ratio magnitude).

================================================================================
Question 908 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 38-year-old woman presents with ptosis and diplopia that tend to worsen as the day progresses. Serology shows antibodies to muscle specific receptor tyrosine kinase. What is the mechanism Of action Of these antibodies?

Options:
  Augments the activity of acetylcholinesterase
  Blocks acetylcholine receptors
  Blocks presynaptic calcium channels
  Damages sarcolemmal membrane
✓ Interfere with trafficking and clustering of acetylcholine receptor

Explanation:
In MuSK-positive Myasthenia Gravis, the antibodies against Muscle Specific Kinase (MuSK) interfere with the clustering and trafficking of Acetylcholine Receptors at the neuromuscular junction, rather than directly blocking the ACh binding site.

================================================================================
Question 909 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
You see a 22yr old male, university student in your clinics. His family reports that he has not been engaging well with them or his friends. His self-care and hygiene has deteriorated and that he has been spending most of his time in his room, keeping the curtains drawn at all times. He has been suspicious of his neighbors and has claimed that they have been telepathically interfering With his brain. At times his family has also noticed that he appears to be smiling and laughing when there is no one around. What is your most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Panic attacks
✓ Paranoid schizophrenia
  Personality disorder
  Post-partum psychosis
  Post-traumatic stress disorder

Explanation:
The patient presents with negative symptoms (social withdrawal, poor hygiene), positive symptoms (bizarre delusions of telepathy, likely hallucinations/laughing at nothing), and suspicion. This syndrome is most consistent with Paranoid Schizophrenia.

================================================================================
Question 910 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 34 year old male presents with worsening headaches. He denies photophobia and phonophobia but complaining of vomiting. The headaches are most severe when he awakens and worsen when he bends over to put on his shoes in the morning. The physical examination, including Fundoscopy, is normal. Which Of the following should be done first?

Options:
  Prescribe ondansetron and obtain a headache diary
✓ MRI of the brain
  Trial of sumatriptan
  Initiate Topiramate
  Lumber puncture

Explanation:
Headaches that are worse in the morning, worse with bending (Valsalva), and associated with vomiting are red flags for increased intracranial pressure (e.g., tumor). Neuroimaging (MRI Brain) is required to rule out a structural lesion.

================================================================================
Question 911 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old woman with Huntington's disease presents with motor difficulties and cognitive impairment. She has had progressive symptoms for several years, including difficulty with speech and swallowing. A CT scan shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen. Which of the following neurotransmitter systems is most directly affected by the loss of neurons in Huntington's disease?

Options:
  Cholinergic system
  Dopaminergic system
✓ GABAergic system
  Noradrenergic system
  Serotonergic system

Explanation:
Huntington's Disease is characterized by the degeneration of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the striatum (caudate and putamen).

================================================================================
Question 912 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A study is performed in which mothers of babies born with neural tube defects are questioned about their acetaminophen consumption during the first trimester of pregnancy. At the same time, mothers of babies born without neural tube defect are also questioned about their consumption of acetaminophen during the first trimester. Which of the following measures of association is most likely to be reported by investigators?

Options:
  Prevalence ratio
  Median survival
  Relative risk
✓ Odds ratio
  Hazard ratio

Explanation:
This is a Case-Control study (selecting subjects based on outcome: defect vs no defect). The measure of association for Case-Control studies is the Odds Ratio.

================================================================================
Question 913 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 22-year-old woman complained to her physician of amenorrhea of 2 months' duration and of a white discharge from her breasts during the past week. The woman had been on haloperidol and paroxetine for 3 months to treat a schizoaffective disorder. She was medication-compliant, and her illness was well controlled. Which of the following mechanisms was most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?

Options:
  Blockade of dopamine receptors in the hypothalamus
  Increased serotonin availability in the pituitary
  Increased serotonin availability in the striatum
✓ Blockade Of dopamine receptors in the pituitary
  Blockade of adrenoceptors in the locus ceruleus

Explanation:
Dopamine normally inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary. Haloperidol blocks D2 dopamine receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway (pituitary), leading to Hyperprolactinemia, which causes galactorrhea and amenorrhea.

================================================================================
Question 914 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 32 year old woman presents to you in your clinic, complaining of intense anxiety and low mood. She is quite tearful during the review and states that she has trouble going out in her car. Upon further questioning she discloses that she was involved in a serious road traffic accident 4 months ago, where two other passengers died. She states that she keeps having flashbacks about this accident and her mood has dipped since then. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  Agoraphobia
  Generalized anxiety disorder
  Panic disorder
✓ post traumatic stress disorder
  Social phobia

Explanation:
The history of a traumatic event (accident) followed by re-experiencing symptoms (flashbacks), avoidance (trouble going in car), and mood changes lasting >1 month is diagnostic of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).

================================================================================
Question 915 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 34year old male is arrested by the police for breaking into a local celebrity's house. The celebrity has disclosed to the police that this person had been constantly stalking and harassing her and sending her messages, gifts and at times following her. Stalking is a serious social issue and most stalkers tend to suffer from a delusional disorder called Erotomania. Which one of the following aids in a correct diagnosis of such an illness?

Options:
✓ A belief that one is loved by another person generally of a higher social status.
  A belief that one is loved by another person generally of a lower social status.
  A belief of being excessively loved and belonging to someone obscure
  A belief of exaggerated self esteem, own abilities and confidence levels
  A belief of being persecuted by someone unknown who has access to them

Explanation:
Erotomania (De Clerambault's syndrome) is a subtype of delusional disorder characterized by the delusion that another person, usually of higher social status or a celebrity, is in love with the individual.

================================================================================
Question 916 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A surgeon accidentally leaves a sponge inside the abdomen after surgery. The patient develops infection and later dies. Which type of negligence has occurred?

Options:
  Civil negligence
  Criminal negligence
✓ Res ipsa loquitur
  Contributory negligence
  Therapeutic misadventure

Explanation:
Res ipsa loquitur ('the thing speaks for itself') applies here. Leaving a foreign body inside a patient is an act so obviously negligent that it requires no further proof of breach of duty.

================================================================================
Question 917 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 38-year-old Caucasian primigravida presents to your office at 20 weeks' gestation for prenatal counseling. She is concerned about the risk of Down syndrome and asks about methods of early diagnosis. You explain that triple screening may detect up to 50% Of cases and amniocentesis may detect up to 90%. She decides not to undergo either test and gives birth to a child with Down syndrome. While comparing both tests during patient counseling you specifically emphasized:

Options:
  Increased false negatives
  Increased false positives
  Increased positive predictive value
  Increased negative predictive value
✓ Increased sensitivity

Explanation:
Comparing detection rates (50% vs 90%) is a comparison of Sensitivity. The doctor explained the Sensitivity of the screening test.

================================================================================
Question 918 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 60 year old man develops severe headache while straining. He is found to have subarachnoid hemorrhage and his cerebral angiogram is normal. Subarachnoid hemorrhage with a normal angiogram is most likely to be associated with which of the following?

Options:
  An anterior cerebral artery aneurysm
  An anterior communicating artery aneurysm
  A middle cerebral artery aneurysm
✓ Perimesencephalic hemorrhage
  Posterior communicating artery aneurysm

Explanation:
A perimesencephalic non-aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage is a distinct entity where blood is localized around the midbrain, and angiography typically fails to show an aneurysm. It usually has a benign course.

================================================================================
Question 919 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 38-year-old man was prescribed citalopram for depression, visits his physician to change his medication due to side effects. Along with it, he also wants to stop smoking as well. To overcome both his depression and dependency on tobacco products, which drug is most likely to be prescribed to this patient?

Options:
  Fluoxetine
  Imipramine
  Paroxetine
  Venlafaxine
✓ Bupropion

Explanation:
Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that is also FDA-approved for smoking cessation (under the name Zyban). It is an excellent choice for treating both conditions simultaneously.

================================================================================
Question 920 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A new screening test is being evaluated for the early detection of stomach cancer. The test relies on measurement of a new serologic marker for gastric adenocarcinoma. The study concludes that, compared to the traditional strategy of endoscopic evaluation Of high-risk patients, the new screening test increases survival by several weeks. This increase in survival is statistically significant, although no difference is detected in rate of radical gastrectomy between two groups. What is most likely to affect the study results presented above?

Options:
  Recall bias
  Confounding
✓ Lead-time bias
  Selection bias
  Low sensitivity

Explanation:
Lead-time bias occurs when screening detects a disease earlier than it would have presented clinically. The patient 'survives' longer from the time of diagnosis simply because diagnosis happened earlier, not because they lived to an older age or the course of the disease changed.

================================================================================
Question 921 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A large-scale clinical trial is being planned to evaluate effect of a non-selective beta-blocker, propranolol, on the clinical course of portal hypertension. The primary outcomes of the study are all-cause mortality and major gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Secondary outcomes are minor gastrointestinal hemorrhage and number of hospitalizations. The investigators are concerned about the possibility that episodes of major gastrointestinal hemorrhage could be over-reported in placebo group. Which is the most useful technique to reduce this possibility?

Options:
  Stratified analysis
  Restriction
  Matching
✓ Blinding
  Randomization

Explanation:
Blinding (specifically the blinding of outcome assessors) prevents Observer Bias, where the knowledge of the treatment group influences the reporting or classification of outcomes.

================================================================================
Question 922 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
Hallucinations, disorientation and confabulation, which is loss of memory for the recent events and filling the gaps with fabricated ones are features of?

Options:
  Acute hallucinosis
  Alcoholic hallucinosis
  Delirium tremens
✓ Korsakoff's psychosis
  Toxic psychosis

Explanation:
Confabulation (fabricating memories to fill gaps) is the hallmark symptom of Korsakoff's Psychosis (Amnestic-Confabulatory Syndrome), a chronic complication of thiamine deficiency in alcoholics.

================================================================================
Question 923 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 24 year old woman who gave birth 4 days earlier presents with a generalized seizure, severe headache, vomiting and blurred vision. She has papilledema on examination. Which of the following investigation would most likely help in the diagnosis?

Options:
  Magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA)
✓ Magnetic resonance venography (MRV)
  Transcranial Doppler scan
  Visual perimetry
  CT angiogram (CTA)

Explanation:
The postpartum state is a hypercoagulable state. The symptoms (seizure, headache, papilledema) are highly suggestive of Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT). Magnetic Resonance Venography (MRV) is the diagnostic test of choice.

================================================================================
Question 924 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 43-year-old man is brought to the hospital with signs of confusion, low blood pressure, tremors, nystagmus, ataxia, mood swings and memory loss. The attendant gives history of chronic alcohol use. The doctor diagnosed his condition as Wernicke Korsakoff syndrome due to prolonged alcohol use. Which of the following should be given to manage this disorder?

Options:
  Alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitors
  Anti Parkinson drugs
  Antipsychotic drugs
  Benzodiazepine
✓ Thiamine supplementation

Explanation:
Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is caused by acute Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. Immediate Thiamine supplementation is required to prevent permanent damage.

================================================================================
Question 925 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A 50-year-old male with bipolar disorder is prescribed lithium carbonate for mood stabilization. During the course of treatment, the patient's sodium levels are closely monitored due to potential interactions. Which of the following describes the interaction between lithium carbonate and sodium?

Options:
✓ Enhances sodium reabsorption in the kidneys
  Increases sodium absorption in the gastrointestinal tract
  Inhibits sodium excretion in sweat glands
  Inhibits sodium uptake in neuronal cells
  Reduces sodium reabsorption in the kidneys

Explanation:
Lithium is handled by the kidney similarly to sodium. If the patient becomes hyponatremic (low sodium), the kidney attempts to conserve sodium and, in the process, increases the reabsorption of Lithium, leading to Lithium toxicity.

================================================================================
Question 926 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
34 year male presented with high grade fever, headache and neck stiffness for last 5 days. He is diagnosed as a case of acute bacterial meningitis. What is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in this age group?

Options:
  Haemophilus influenzae
  Neisseria meningitidis
  Staphylococcus aureus
✓ Streptococcus pneumoniae
  Listeria monocytogenes

Explanation:
Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired bacterial meningitis in adults.

================================================================================
Question 927 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A man suffering from schizophrenia kills his wife during a psychotic episode. He claims that he heard "divine voices" ordering him to do so. Which is the key question under McNaughten rule?

Options:
  Could he resist his impulse?
  Was he mentally ill?
✓ Did he know the nature and quality of the act or that it was wrong?
  Did he have a personality disorder?
  Did he know the legal consequences Of his act?

Explanation:
The McNaughten Rule (insanity defense) asks two specific questions: 1) Did the defendant know the nature and quality of the act? or 2) Did the defendant know that what he was doing was wrong?

================================================================================
Question 928 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A male has multiple nodules on skin. These nodules are excised and sent to laboratory . Microscopic examination of the nodule shows a well circumscribed lesion composed of spindle shaped cells having wavy spindle shaped nuclei. NO mitosis or necrosis seen.

Options:
  Astrocytoma
✓ Neurofibroma
  meningioma
  oligodendroglioma
  germinoma

Explanation:
The description of "spindle shaped cells with wavy nuclei" (often described as buckled or comma-shaped) is the classic histologic appearance of a Neurofibroma.

================================================================================
Question 929 (NWSM - 2025)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient survives an overdose of sedative pills. He is drowsy but easily arousable, respiration normal. Which drug is most likely involved?

Options:
  Phenobarbital
✓ Diazepam
  Chloral hydrate
  Paraldehyde
  Methaqualone

Explanation:
Benzodiazepines (like Diazepam) have a high therapeutic index. In pure overdose, they typically cause drowsiness and ataxia but rarely cause significant respiratory depression or coma unless combined with other depressants (unlike Barbiturates).

================================================================================
Question 930 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The triad of consequences consisting of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications are most likely associated with which of the following infections?

Options:
  a. Tuberculous meningitis
  b. Bacterial meningitis
  c. Fungal Encephalitis
  d. Cysticercosis
✓ e. Cerebral Toxoplasmosis

Explanation:
The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis consists of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.

================================================================================
Question 931 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following fungi has the proclivity to invade the brain directly through the cribriform plate rather than via hematogenous dissemination?

Options:
  a. Candida
✓ b. Mucormycosis
  c. Aspergillus
  d. Histoplasma
  e. Blastomyces

Explanation:
Mucormycosis (Rhizopus species) typically invades the brain directly from the nasal sinuses through the cribriform plate, causing rhinocerebral mucormycosis.

================================================================================
Question 932 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The pattern of involvement of CNS in TB is:

Options:
✓ a. Meningitis
  b. Brain abscess
  c. Meningoencephalitis
  d. Cerebral gummas
  e. Encephalitis

Explanation:
Tuberculous meningitis is the most common presentation of neurotuberculosis, typically affecting the base of the brain (basal meningitis).

================================================================================
Question 933 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 55-year-old man presents with a history of headaches and seizures. CT reveals a mass in the left cerebral hemisphere. Biopsy of the mass reveals increased cellularity, cells with marked nuclear pleomorphism, necrosis, and vascular endothelial proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  a. Gemistocytic Astrocytoma
✓ b. Glioblastoma
  c. Medulloblastoma
  d. Meningioma
  e. Pilocytic Astrocytoma

Explanation:
The histological features of marked pleomorphism, necrosis (often pseudopalisading), and microvascular proliferation are diagnostic of Glioblastoma (WHO Grade IV).

================================================================================
Question 934 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A mass removed surgically measuring 4 cm lying beneath the dura compressing the right superolateral lobe. On histology, pale oblong nuclei and pink cytoplasm with occasional psammoma bodies are noted. This is most likely a:

Options:
  a. Medulloblastoma
  b. Tuberculoma
✓ c. Meningioma
  d. Ependymoma
  e. Schwannoma

Explanation:
Meningiomas are extra-axial tumors (beneath the dura) characterized histologically by whorled cells with psammoma bodies.

================================================================================
Question 935 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhage is:

Options:
✓ a. Hypertension
  b. Berry aneurysm
  c. Fusiform aneurysm
  d. Vascular malformation
  e. Bleeding diathesis

Explanation:
Hypertension is the leading cause of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, typically affecting deep brain structures like the basal ganglia.

================================================================================
Question 936 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Intra-cytoplasmic inclusion bodies called neurofibrillary tangles are characteristic of:

Options:
  a. Parkinson's disease
  b. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
✓ c. Alzheimer's disease
  d. Gliosis
  e. Alexander disease

Explanation:
Neurofibrillary tangles (composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein) and amyloid plaques are the hallmark pathological features of Alzheimer's disease.

================================================================================
Question 937 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Multiple sclerosis is:

Options:
  a. A disease with a rapidly progressive course
  b. Characterized by focal necrosis of the spinal cord
  c. Presents with pre-senile dementia
  d. Usually seen in the elderly
✓ e. An auto-immune condition

Explanation:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system.

================================================================================
Question 938 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 66-year-old man is finding that he has more difficulty getting up and moving about for the past year. He is annoyed by a tremor in his hands, but the tremor goes away when he performs routine tasks using his hands. Which of the following conditions is he most likely to have?

Options:
✓ a. Parkinson's Disease
  b. Huntington Disease
  c. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
  d. Niemann-Pick Disease
  e. Tuberous Sclerosis

Explanation:
The clinical presentation of bradykinesia (difficulty moving) and a resting tremor (disappears with action) is characteristic of Parkinson's Disease.

================================================================================
Question 939 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient with a recent viral infection complains of fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Upon taking a CSF sample, it is determined that there are no bacteria present and the protein levels are elevated. What happens to glucose levels if the patient were infected with E. coli?

Options:
  a. Increase
✓ b. Decrease
  c. Stay the same
  d. Irrelevant at this level
  e. Only elevated when proteins are elevated

Explanation:
E. coli causes bacterial meningitis, which is characterized by a significant decrease in CSF glucose levels (hypoglycorrhachia) as bacteria consume glucose.

================================================================================
Question 940 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Pathophysiologically, which is the most important reason for the precipitation of seizures?

Options:
  a. Increased Glutamate, Increased GABA
  b. Increased AMPA, Increased GABA
✓ c. Increased Glutamate, Decreased GABA
  d. Decreased Glutamate, Increased GABA
  e. Decreased Glutamate, Decreased AMPA

Explanation:
Seizures result from an imbalance between excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission, specifically increased excitation (Glutamate) and decreased inhibition (GABA).

================================================================================
Question 941 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following inhalational anesthetics has a low blood gas partition coefficient but is not used for induction of anesthesia because of airway irritation?

Options:
✓ a. Desflurane
  b. Halothane
  c. Enflurane
  d. Isoflurane
  e. Sevoflurane

Explanation:
Desflurane has a very low blood-gas partition coefficient (fast onset/offset) but is extremely pungent, causing airway irritation, coughing, and laryngospasm, making it unsuitable for inhalation induction.

================================================================================
Question 942 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following drugs causes malignant hyperthermia?

Options:
  a. Decamethonium
✓ b. Halothane
  c. Isoflurane
  d. Ketamine
  e. Nitrous oxide

Explanation:
Malignant hyperthermia is a rare, life-threatening reaction triggered by volatile anesthetics (like Halothane, Isoflurane) and succinylcholine. Halothane is a classic trigger.

================================================================================
Question 943 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following drugs may cause an increase in intraocular pressure?

Options:
  a. Amoxicillin
  b. Dopamine
✓ c. Ketamine
  d. Phenytoin sodium
  e. Propranolol

Explanation:
Ketamine increases cerebral blood flow and can increase intraocular pressure, making it potentially hazardous in patients with open-globe injuries or glaucoma.

================================================================================
Question 944 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Respiratory depression after the use of which of the following agents may be reversed by the administration of flumazenil?

Options:
  a. Desflurane
  b. Fentanyl
  c. Ketamine
✓ d. Midazolam
  e. Morphine

Explanation:
Flumazenil is a specific benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used to reverse the sedative and respiratory depressant effects of benzodiazepines like Midazolam.

================================================================================
Question 945 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient is to undergo brief general anesthesia for surgery. The safest and the fastest-acting inhalation general anesthetic would be:

Options:
  a. Enflurane
  b. Halothane
  c. Isoflurane
  d. Nitrogen dioxide
✓ e. Nitrous oxide

Explanation:
Nitrous oxide has the lowest blood:gas partition coefficient among the options, allowing for the fastest induction and recovery, although it is a weak anesthetic.

================================================================================
Question 946 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is the drug of choice in trigeminal neuralgia?

Options:
✓ a. Carbamazepine
  b. Levodopa
  c. Methyldopa
  d. Phenobarbitone
  e. Phenytoin

Explanation:
Carbamazepine is the first-line drug of choice for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia.

================================================================================
Question 947 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20-year-old man with absence seizures is treated with ethosuximide. Which of the following is the principle mechanism of action of ethosuximide?

Options:
  a. Increase in GABA
  b. Increase in the frequency of the chloride channel opening
  c. L-type of calcium channel blockade
  d. Sodium channel blockade
✓ e. T-type of calcium channel blockade

Explanation:
Ethosuximide works by blocking T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, which are responsible for generating the 3Hz spike-and-wave pattern in absence seizures.

================================================================================
Question 948 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A hypertensive crisis is more likely to result from the action of drugs from which one of the following drug classes?

Options:
  a. Barbiturates
  b. Benzodiazepines
✓ c. Monoamine oxidase inhibitor
  d. Opioids
  e. Tricyclic antidepressants

Explanation:
MAO inhibitors can cause a hypertensive crisis ('cheese reaction') when consumed with tyramine-rich foods, as tyramine displaces stored catecholamines.

================================================================================
Question 949 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 12-year-old boy with generalized tonic seizures develops an overgrowth of gum tissue. The patient was most likely taking which of the following agents?

Options:
  a. Clonazepam
  b. Ethosuximide
  c. Phenobarbital
✓ d. Phenytoin
  e. Primidone

Explanation:
Gingival hyperplasia (gum overgrowth) is a well-known side effect of long-term Phenytoin therapy.

================================================================================
Question 950 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 72-year-old patient with parkinsonism presents with swollen feet, which are red, tender, and very painful. These symptoms will decrease within a few days if the patient were to stop taking:

Options:
  a. Amantadine
  b. Benztropine
✓ c. Bromocriptine
  d. Levodopa
  e. Selegiline

Explanation:
Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, can cause erythromelalgia (red, tender, painful swollen feet).

================================================================================
Question 951 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 20-year-old lady has been admitted under your care as a case of suspected poisoning. Her pupils are dilated, she is delirious, and also has hyperpyrexia. What is the appropriate antidote for this case?

Options:
  a. Atropine
  b. Flumazenil
  c. Morphine
  d. Naloxone
✓ e. Physostigmine

Explanation:
The symptoms (dilated pupils, delirium, hyperpyrexia, dry skin) suggest anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., Datura/Atropine). Physostigmine is the antidote.

================================================================================
Question 952 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A drug addict gives a history of tactile sensations all over his body. Which drug is he likely to have consumed?

Options:
  a. Alcohol
  b. Cannabis
✓ c. Cocaine
  d. Heroin
  e. Opium

Explanation:
Tactile hallucinations, often described as bugs crawling under the skin (Magnan's symptoms or 'cocaine bugs'), are characteristic of chronic Cocaine abuse.

================================================================================
Question 953 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which drug is commonly used in body packer syndrome?

Options:
  a. Alcohol
  b. Benzodiazepine
  c. Cannabis
✓ d. Diacetylmorphine
  e. Ganja

Explanation:
Body packer syndrome involves swallowing packets of drugs for trafficking. Heroin (Diacetylmorphine) and Cocaine are the most commonly involved drugs.

================================================================================
Question 954 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
The drug which causes drowsiness and facilitates sleep, which is close to the normal pattern and the patient can be aroused easily, is called a:

Options:
  a. Analgesic
  b. Anesthetic
  c. Deliriant
✓ d. Hypnotic
  e. Sedative

Explanation:
A hypnotic is a drug that induces sleep resembling natural sleep, from which the patient can be aroused.

================================================================================
Question 955 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Bullous lesions on the fingers, buttocks, and around the knees are observed in which acute poisoning?

Options:
✓ a. Barbiturate
  b. Cocaine
  c. Opium
  d. Alcohol
  e. Strychnine

Explanation:
Cutaneous bullae (barbiturate blisters) on pressure areas are a characteristic finding in acute Barbiturate poisoning.

================================================================================
Question 956 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
In which poisoning case is drug automatism mostly seen?

Options:
✓ a. Barbiturate
  b. Cannabis
  c. Chloral hydrate
  d. Cocaine
  e. Opium

Explanation:
Drug automatism is a phenomenon where a patient forgets they have already taken a dose and takes repeated doses, leading to toxicity. It is classically associated with Barbiturates.

================================================================================
Question 957 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Cold Turkey is referred to the withdrawal effect of which substance?

Options:
  a. Aconite
  b. Dhatura
✓ c. Morphine
  d. Oleander
  e. Strychnine

Explanation:
'Cold Turkey' refers to the abrupt withdrawal symptoms (piloerection/gooseflesh) seen in opioid (Morphine/Heroin) addiction.

================================================================================
Question 958 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the shape of the pupil in opium poisoning?

Options:
  a. Alternately contracted & dilated
  b. Contracted
  c. Dilated
  d. Mid dilated
✓ e. Pinpoint

Explanation:
Pinpoint pupils (miosis) are a hallmark sign of opioid (opium) poisoning.

================================================================================
Question 959 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the color of lividity in opium poisoning?

Options:
  a. Blue
✓ b. Black
  c. Cherry red
  d. Pink
  e. Red

Explanation:
In opium poisoning, death is due to respiratory depression/asphyxia, leading to deep blue or blackish post-mortem lividity.

================================================================================
Question 960 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Opium is the dried juice of which of the following plants?

Options:
  a. Capsicum annuum
  b. Cannabis sativa
  c. Datura fastuosa
✓ d. Papaver somniferum
  e. Strychnos nux-vomica

Explanation:
Opium is obtained from the unripe capsule of the poppy plant, Papaver somniferum.

================================================================================
Question 961 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one is used as a truth serum?

Options:
  a. Alcohol
  b. Cocaine
  c. Morphine
  d. Opium
✓ e. Thiopentone sodium

Explanation:
Thiopentone sodium (a barbiturate) is used in narcoanalysis as a 'truth serum' to lower inhibitions.

================================================================================
Question 962 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning?

Options:
  a. Diazepam
✓ b. Flumazenil
  c. Morphine
  d. Pentobarbitone
  e. Thiopentone

Explanation:
Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.

================================================================================
Question 963 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which one is correct regarding rigor mortis in deaths due to strychnine poisoning?

Options:
  a. Sets in late and passes off early
  b. Sets in early and passes off late
✓ c. Sets in early and passes off early
  d. Sets in late and passes off late
  e. Sets in and passes off irregularly

Explanation:
In conditions involving violent convulsions and exhaustion (like strychnine poisoning), rigor mortis sets in very early and passes off early.

================================================================================
Question 964 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which poison can resist putrefaction and can be recovered from putrefied exhumed bodies?

Options:
  a. Cannabis
  b. Chloral hydrate
  c. Cocaine
  d. Opium
✓ e. Strychnine

Explanation:
Strychnine is a stable alkaloid that resists putrefaction and can be detected in bodies years after death.

================================================================================
Question 965 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
How many crushed seeds of Strychnos nux-vomica can be proved fatal?

Options:
✓ a. 1-2 seeds
  b. 4-6 seeds
  c. 6-8 seeds
  d. 8-10 seeds
  e. 10-12 seeds

Explanation:
One crushed seed of Nux vomica (containing strychnine) contains enough alkaloid to be fatal.

================================================================================
Question 966 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following diseases has resemblance with strychnine poisoning?

Options:
  a. Cholera
  b. Encephalitis
  c. Migraine
  d. Renal tubular necrosis
✓ e. Tetanus

Explanation:
Strychnine poisoning causes tetanic convulsions and opisthotonos, closely resembling Tetanus.

================================================================================
Question 967 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
An ICU patient has an intra-arterial cannula placed after cardiac surgery to monitor systolic blood pressure (SBP). Twenty-four SBP values are recorded over a period of six hours, with a maximum value of 141 mmHg and a minimum value of 96 mmHg. If the next SBP recording is 200 mmHg, which of the following is most likely to remain unchanged?

Options:
  a. Mean
✓ b. Mode
  c. Range
  d. Variance
  e. Standard deviation

Explanation:
The mode is the most frequent value. Adding a single extreme outlier (200 mmHg) is unlikely to change the most frequent value, whereas mean, range, variance, and SD are all sensitive to outliers.

================================================================================
Question 968 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A rare disorder of amino acid metabolism causes severe mental retardation if left untreated. If the disease is detected soon after birth, a restrictive diet prevents mental abnormalities. Which of the following characteristics would be most desirable in a screening test for this disease?

Options:
✓ a. High Sensitivity
  b. High Specificity
  c. High Positive predictive value
  d. High Cutoff value
  e. High Accuracy

Explanation:
For a serious condition where early treatment prevents severe consequences (like PKU), a screening test must have high sensitivity to ensure no cases are missed (few false negatives).

================================================================================
Question 969 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A 52-year-old female presents to your office with a self-palpated thyroid nodule. After the appropriate work-up, fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of the nodule is performed. The FNA result is negative. As you are explaining the test result, the patient asks, 'What are the chances that I really do not have cancer?' You reply that the probability of thyroid cancer is low in her case because FNA has a high:

Options:
  a. Specificity
  b. Sensitivity
  c. Positive predictive value
✓ d. Negative predictive value
  e. Validity

Explanation:
Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the probability that a person with a negative test result truly does not have the disease.

================================================================================
Question 970 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
2500 women aged 40-54 who present for routine check-ups are asked about their meat consumption. 20% of the women turn out to be vegetarian. During the ensuing 5 years, 5 vegetarians and 43 non-vegetarians develop colorectal cancer. Which of the following best describes the study design?

Options:
  a. Case Series Report
✓ b. Cohort Study
  c. Case-Control Study
  d. Cross-Sectional Study
  e. Randomized Clinical Trial

Explanation:
The study starts with exposure status (vegetarian vs non-vegetarian) and follows participants forward in time to observe the outcome (cancer), which is the definition of a Cohort Study.

================================================================================
Question 971 (RMC - 2023)
================================================================================

Question:
A study in which children are randomly assigned to receive either a newly formulated vaccine or the currently available vaccine, and are followed to monitor for side effects and effectiveness of each vaccine, is an example of which type of study?

Options:
  a. Experimental
  b. Observational
  c. Cohort
  d. Case-control
✓ e. Clinical trial

Explanation:
Random assignment of an intervention (vaccine) to human subjects to evaluate efficacy and safety is a Clinical Trial (Experimental study).
