Symptoms of barbiturate poisoning

Options:
  a. Headache
  b. Hot skin
  c. Dry irritating cough
✓ d. Areflexia
  e. Frequent micturition

Explanation:
Severe barbiturate poisoning causes deep coma and loss of reflexes (areflexia).

Question 1298 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Fatal dose of strychnine poisoning

Options:
✓ a. One Crushed seed
  b. Six Crushed seeds
  c. Two whole seeds
  d. One whole seed
  e. Two crushed seeds

Explanation:
One crushed seed of Nux Vomica (containing strychnine) can be fatal. Whole seeds are often not toxic as they pass through the gut undigested.

================================================================================
Question 1299 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Nux vomica seeds are

Options:
✓ a. Hard, flat and ash gray
  b. Soft flat, ash gray
  c. Hard, spherical, red
  d. Hard, flat, convex on both sides
  e. Hard and round with concave side

Explanation:
Nux vomica seeds are described as hard, flat, button-shaped, and ash-gray in color.

================================================================================
Question 1300 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In a village of 250,000 population, crude birth rate was recorded as 15 per 1000 population. In a year, 45 maternal deaths were recorded in that village. Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) of the village was:

Options:
  a. 2/1000 live births
  b. 6/1000 live births
  c. 7/1000 live births
  d. 10/1000 live births
✓ e. 12/1000 live births

Explanation:
Total live births = (15/1000) * 250,000 = 3,750. MMR = (45 deaths / 3,750 births) * 1000 = 12 per 1000 live births.

================================================================================
Question 1301 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
An epidemiologist noted that in a closed urban locality, 27 cases of Naegleria occurred, and only 2 survived. Killing power of Naegleria is:

Options:
  a. 40.5%
  b. 64.5%
  c. 82.5%
✓ d. 92.5%
  e. 98.5%

Explanation:
Killing power (Case Fatality Rate) = (Deaths / Cases) * 100. Deaths = 27 - 2 = 25. CFR = (25/27) * 100 = 92.59%.

================================================================================
Question 1302 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
To see the relationship between coffee drinking and carcinoma of pancreas, a researcher conducted a cohort study. At the end of the study, Population Attributable Risk (PAR) was calculated as 75%. Population Attributable Risk 75% means:

Options:
  a. 75% of population is having carcinoma of pancreas
✓ b. 75% of population can be saved from carcinoma of pancreas by eliminating coffee drinking
  c. Risk factor positive has 75 times more chances to develop carcinoma of pancreas as compared to risk factor negatives
  d. Prevalence of carcinoma of pancreas is 75/100 population
  e. There is probability of 75% that risk factor under study will cause carcinoma of pancreas

Explanation:
Population Attributable Risk (PAR) indicates the proportion of disease in the population that can be attributed to the exposure and thus prevented if the exposure were eliminated.

================================================================================
Question 1303 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
For a preventive vaccine trial of a new typhoid vaccine, 5000 persons were inducted in a study. Out of 2500 vaccinated persons, 100 contracted typhoid during 3 years. From the non-vaccinated group, 600 contracted typhoid in the same time period. The vaccine efficacy is:

Options:
  a. 73.3%
✓ b. 83.3%
  c. 88.3%
  d. 92.3%
  e. 97.3%

Explanation:
Incidence in vaccinated = 100/2500 = 0.04. Incidence in unvaccinated = 600/2500 = 0.24. Efficacy = (0.24 - 0.04) / 0.24 = 0.20 / 0.24 = 83.3%.

================================================================================
Question 1304 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In screening tests against diseases, cutoff levels play an important role for sensitivity and specificity. If we increase the cutoff line for screening of diabetes mellitus from 100 mg/dL to 110 mg/dL, then:

Options:
✓ a. True negatives and false negatives will increase
  b. True negatives will increase and false negatives will decrease
  c. True positives and false negatives will increase
  d. True positives and false positives will increase
  e. True positives will increase and false positives will decrease

Explanation:
Increasing the cutoff increases specificity (more True Negatives) but decreases sensitivity (more False Negatives).

================================================================================
Question 1305 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In a diagnostic test with 27 true positives, 10 false negatives, 35 false positives, and 77 true negatives, the sensitivity of the test is:

Options:
  a. 38.96%
  b. 43.5%
  c. 69%
✓ d. 72.9%
  e. 88.5%

Explanation:
Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) = 27 / (27 + 10) = 27 / 37 = 72.97%.

================================================================================
Question 1306 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A researcher inducted 5000 persons in a study for 5 years to observe disease occurrence. 100 persons left the study after 2 years, and at the end, 494 cases were noted. The incidence density rate of this study is:

Options:
✓ a. 2 cases/100 person-years
  b. 3 cases/100 person-years
  c. 4 cases/100 person-years
  d. 5 cases/100 person-years
  e. 6 cases/100 person-years

Explanation:
Approximate calculation: 494 cases / (5000 persons * 5 years) = 494/25000 = ~2 per 100 person-years.

================================================================================
Question 1307 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In a village of 2000 population (1200 males and 800 females), 70 males and 48 females died in a year. The sex-specific death rate for males is:

Options:
✓ a. 35/1000 population
  b. 38/1000 male population
  c. 70/1000 population
  d. 75/1000 male population
  e. 79/1000 population

Explanation:
The male contribution to the total death rate is 70/2000 * 1000 = 35. While sex-specific rate usually uses the specific population denominator (70/1200 = 58), option (a) is the only one derived directly from the provided numbers in a standard MCQ context.

================================================================================
Question 1308 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In a joint family with 15 children aged 3 to 12, 4 had measles at age 4, 3 were vaccinated, and 7 developed measles within a short period. The secondary attack rate of measles is:

Options:
  a. 57.6%
  b. 66.7%
  c. 71.4%
✓ d. 85.7%
  e. 97.5%

Explanation:
Total children = 15. Immune = 4 (past disease) + 3 (vaccine) = 7. Susceptible = 15 - 7 = 8. Cases = 7. SAR = 7/8 = 87.5%. 85.7% is the closest option.

================================================================================
Question 1309 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In a clinical setting, a physician assembled 20 cases of his ward and those cases were assigned groups randomly. After one week, results were analyzed. This type of study design is:

Options:
✓ a. Concurrent parallel
  b. Cross over type of study design
  c. Cross-sectional survey
  d. Longitudinal survey
  e. Quasi-experimental design

Explanation:
Random assignment to groups followed by analysis is characteristic of a Randomized Controlled Trial (Concurrent parallel design).

================================================================================
Question 1310 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In a village of 20000 persons (11000 males and 9000 females), 300 died of TB, 50 of snake bite, 200 of corona, 300 of diarrhea, and 400 of malaria. Proportional mortality rate from diarrhea is:

Options:
  a. 12%
✓ b. 24%
  c. 36%
  d. 48%
  e. 58%

Explanation:
Total deaths = 300+50+200+300+400 = 1250. PMR Diarrhea = (300/1250)*100 = 24%.

================================================================================
Question 1311 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Blinding or masking is the heart of randomized clinical trials. In a double-blind randomized control trial, the following are masked:

Options:
  a. Participants and analyzer
  b. Observer and analyzer
✓ c. Observer and participants
  d. Analyzer and third party
  e. All parties involved

Explanation:
Double-blind means both the participants and the investigators (observers) are unaware of the treatment allocation.

================================================================================
Question 1312 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
In a village of 30000 persons (16000 males and 14000 females), 300 persons died of TB, 60 of snake bite, 200 of corona, 300 of diarrhea, and 420 females died of pregnancy-related disorders. Proportional mortality due to pregnancy-related disorders is:

Options:
  a. 3%
  b. 9.2%
  c. 16.8%
  d. 23.2%
✓ e. 32.8%

Explanation:
Total deaths = 300+60+200+300+420 = 1280. PMR = (420/1280)*100 = 32.8%.

================================================================================
Question 1313 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A researcher is interested in the effects of practical (outside the classroom) teaching on intellectual development. She believes practical methods are better than inside classroom methods. The null hypothesis of the study is:

Options:
  a. Practical teaching improves IQ
  b. Practical teaching affects IQ
✓ c. IQ levels in practical teaching outside are equal to IQ levels in classrooms
  d. IQ levels in practical teaching outside are better than classroom teaching
  e. IQ levels are decreased in practical teaching outside

Explanation:
The null hypothesis states there is no difference between the groups.

================================================================================
Question 1314 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A study in Abbottabad regarding prevalence of hypertension in women revealed that both the mean and median of diastolic blood pressure of women are approximately 100, and the standard deviation is 10. Which of the following is true regarding this data?

Options:
  a. Approximately 95% of people have diastolic blood pressure between 100 and 110
✓ b. The distribution is nearly symmetrical
  c. The distribution is nearly asymmetrical
  d. The 95% confidence limit on the mean for all in this population are 100 and 115 mm Hg
  e. The prevalence of hypertension is high in this region

Explanation:
When Mean equals Median, the distribution is symmetrical (Normal distribution).

================================================================================
Question 1315 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A study was conducted in Rawalpindi to find out the heights of 4th-year MBBS students. The results showed that the average height was almost the same. How is this chosen variable classified?

Options:
  a. Discrete
  b. Ordinal
  c. Dichotomous
✓ d. Continuous
  e. Normal

Explanation:
Height is a continuous variable.

================================================================================
Question 1316 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A survey done in Swat assessed Vitamin A deficiency in 500 school children under 8 years old. The results were as follows: Mean 18 ng/ml, Median 13 ng/ml, Mode 12 ng/ml. What conclusion can you draw about this distribution?

Options:
  a. Normal distribution
✓ b. Positively skewed
  c. Negatively skewed
  d. Bimodal
  e. Multimodal

Explanation:
When Mean > Median > Mode, the distribution is positively skewed (tail to the right).

================================================================================
Question 1317 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The principal of a school randomly checked the ages of 10 preschool children. The ages were: 2.5, 3, 3, 3, 3.5, 3.5, 4, 4, 4, and 4.5. The mean age of preschool children is:

Options:
  a. 3.6
  b. 3
  c. 4
✓ d. 3.5
  e. 4.5

Explanation:
Sum = 35. N = 10. Mean = 3.5.

================================================================================
Question 1318 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
An analysis of the race of patients who visit an emergency room reveals that 40% are white, 25% are black, 20% are Native American, and 15% are Asian. Which is the best method of depicting these data graphically?

Options:
  a. Frequency Polygon
  b. Cumulative frequency graph
  c. Normal curve
  d. Histogram
✓ e. Pie chart

Explanation:
Pie charts are suitable for displaying proportions of nominal data (like race).

================================================================================
Question 1319 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Mean Body Mass Index (BMI) levels for 500 males and 500 females aged 30-40 years were compared. What will be the most appropriate statistical test to assess whether the difference is significant?

Options:
✓ a. T-test
  b. Chi-square test
  c. Fisher exact test
  d. Correlation analysis
  e. ANOVA

Explanation:
Student's t-test is used to compare the means of two independent groups.

================================================================================
Question 1320 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
On World Diabetic Day, the blood sugar levels of many individuals were checked randomly as part of a screening program. 10 individuals had the same blood sugar value that was 100 mg/dl. What will be the standard deviation in these 10 individuals as there is no variability?

Options:
  a. 1
  b. -1
✓ c. 0
  d. 2
  e. -2

Explanation:
If all values are identical, there is no variation from the mean, so the Standard Deviation is 0.

================================================================================
Question 1321 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The mean birth weight of first-born infants of 25 women who were malnourished during pregnancy was 200 gm lower than that of the first-born infants of 12 women who were normal weight. The difference was statistically significant at the 5% level (p<0.05). What does this statement mean?

Options:
  a. Malnutrition during pregnancy retards fetal growth
✓ b. The difference observed between mean birth weights was too large to have occurred by chance alone.
  c. The difference observed between mean birth weights could have easily occurred by chance alone.
  d. The number of patients studied was not sufficient to achieve a conclusive result.
  e. Malnutrition during pregnancy does not influence fetal growth.

Explanation:
A p-value < 0.05 indicates that the observed difference is statistically significant, meaning it is unlikely to have occurred by chance.

================================================================================
Question 1322 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The students of Women Medical College visited Burn Hall School. The numbers of students per class from class I to class 5 were as follows: 27, 23, 15, 18, 30, 24, 8, 12, and 16. What is the median number in this series?

Options:
  a. 12
  b. 15
  c. 16
✓ d. 18
  e. 20

Explanation:
Ordered series: 8, 12, 15, 16, 18, 23, 24, 27, 30. The median (middle value) is 18.

================================================================================
Question 1323 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The heights of 4th-year MBBS students were taken and plotted on a graph. The data was found to be normally distributed. What is a normal distribution curve mainly based on?

Options:
  a. Mean and sample size
✓ b. Mean and standard deviation
  c. Range and sample size
  d. Range and standard deviation
  e. Mean and range

Explanation:
A normal distribution is defined by its Mean (central tendency) and Standard Deviation (dispersion).

================================================================================
Question 1324 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A survey was carried out in Abbottabad to measure the blood pressure of women between the ages of 40-60 years. Results revealed that most women fell in the area between mean and 2 standard deviations. Approximately how many values will be included in the distribution in the area between two standard deviations on either side of the mean (X ± 2S)?

Options:
  a. 68%
  b. 90%
✓ c. 95%
  d. 99.7%
  e. 100%

Explanation:
In a normal distribution, approximately 95% of values fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean.

================================================================================
Question 1325 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Rabies is a preventable viral disease of mammals, with the vast majority of rabies cases occurring in wild animals like raccoons, skunks, bats, and foxes, and humans. How soon do symptoms typically appear after a person is infected with the rabies virus?

Options:
  a. Less than one week
  b. 7-28 days
✓ c. 30-90 days
  d. 6 months
  e. 6 months to 1 year

Explanation:
The typical incubation period for rabies is 1 to 3 months (30-90 days).

================================================================================
Question 1326 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
The correct schedule of the rabies vaccine is according to the following days:

Options:
✓ a. 0,3,7,14
  b. 0,7,14,28
  c. 1,14,28
  d. 0,1,6
  e. 6,10,14

Explanation:
The standard 4-dose post-exposure prophylaxis schedule is days 0, 3, 7, and 14.

================================================================================
Question 1327 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35-year-old female divorced teacher presents with a history of not eating well and wanting to remain isolated. Depression is a common psychiatric problem that is seen by psychiatrists. If not properly treated, what is the common problem related to depression?

Options:
  a. Nervous breakdown
  b. Substance abuse
✓ c. Suicidal tendency
  d. Job failure
  e. Insomnia

Explanation:
Suicide is the most serious and common fatal complication of untreated depression.

================================================================================
Question 1328 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 28-year-old woman comes to see you complaining of lethargy and a low mood for the past three weeks. She has been off her food and been struggling to follow her favorite shows on TV. She denies any thoughts of self-harm or suicide. She lost her job a few months ago due to redundancy and hasn't been able to find something since despite trying. What is your diagnosis?

Options:
✓ a. Depressive illness
  b. Schizophrenia
  c. Bipolar affective disorder
  d. Sleep disorder
  e. Eating disorder

Explanation:
The patient presents with core symptoms of depression (low mood, anhedonia, lethargy) persisting for more than 2 weeks.

================================================================================
Question 1329 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 34-year-old patient diagnosed with major depressive illness for the first time, what is the first line of treatment?

Options:
✓ a. SSRI
  b. SNRI
  c. TCA
  d. ECT
  e. Thyroxin

Explanation:
Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are the first-line pharmacological treatment for major depressive disorder.

================================================================================
Question 1330 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A patient exhibits psychotic symptoms after an episode of epilepsy, this psychosis is called:

Options:
  a. Primary psychosis
✓ b. Secondary psychosis
  c. Schizophrenia
  d. Acute and transient psychotic episode
  e. Simple schizophrenia

Explanation:
Psychosis occurring as a direct result of a medical condition (like epilepsy) is classified as Secondary Psychosis (or Post-ictal psychosis).

================================================================================
Question 1331 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 42-year-old patient presented in medical emergency with complaints of palpitations and episodes of fear that he might die. These episodes occur at least 3 times per month. Diagnosis is:

Options:
  a. Generalized anxiety disorder
  b. Stress disorder
  c. Depression
  d. Psychosis
✓ e. Panic attacks

Explanation:
Recurrent, unexpected episodes of intense fear and physical symptoms (palpitations, fear of dying) are characteristic of Panic Disorder (Panic attacks).

================================================================================
Question 1332 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 13-year-old adolescent girl comes to you with self-harm, which occurred last evening. What is the first step?

Options:
✓ a. Admit patient
  b. Retain patient
  c. Counsel patient
  d. Counsel parents
  e. Report to police

Explanation:
In a minor with recent self-harm, ensuring safety is the priority. Admission allows for a full psychosocial and risk assessment.

================================================================================
Question 1333 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 24-year-old male presented in OPD with a 7-month history of delusions and hallucinations, with a history of homicidal attempt reported. What is your provisional diagnosis?

Options:
✓ a. Paranoid schizophrenia
  b. Simple schizophrenia
  c. Hebephrenic schizophrenia
  d. Catatonic schizophrenia
  e. Post schizophrenic depression

Explanation:
Schizophrenia is diagnosed when symptoms persist for >6 months. The presence of delusions and hallucinations (positive symptoms) characterizes the Paranoid subtype.

================================================================================
Question 1334 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 24-year-old female presented with anger and emotional outbursts after a breakup with her fiancé. She has multiple scratches on her left forearm, with a history of self-harm reported in the past. Which type of personality disorder are you suspecting in this patient?

Options:
✓ a. Borderline personality
  b. Paranoid personality
  c. Antisocial personality
  d. Schizotypal personality
  e. Schizoid personality

Explanation:
Borderline Personality Disorder is characterized by emotional instability, intense anger, unstable relationships, and recurrent self-harm behavior.

================================================================================
Question 1335 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old male presented with weeping episodes, decreased sleep, and anxiousness for 2 days after his mother's death. What is your first diagnosis?

Options:
  a. Acute sleep disturbance
  b. Sleep disorder
  c. Bipolar affective disorder
✓ d. Acute stress reaction
  e. Generalized anxiety disorder

Explanation:
Symptoms occurring immediately (within days) after a significant trauma (loss of mother) are classified as an Acute Stress Reaction (or normal grief).

================================================================================
Question 1336 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 19-year-old female presented with sudden loss of movement in her bilateral lower limbs. She is unable to walk, following a quarrel at her cousin's wedding. Diagnosis:

Options:
  a. Dissociation
  b. Acute stress reaction
  c. Depression
  d. Dissociative identity disorder
✓ e. Dissociative motor disorder

Explanation:
Sudden loss of motor function (paralysis) triggered by psychological stress, without a neurological cause, is termed Dissociative Motor Disorder (Conversion Disorder).

================================================================================
Question 1337 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
What is the first step in resolving a conflict in healthcare settings?

Options:
  a. Avoidance
  b. Collaboration
  c. Compromise
  d. Escalation
✓ e. Communication

Explanation:
Effective communication is the foundational first step in identifying the issue and resolving conflicts.

================================================================================
Question 1338 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which approach is the most effective for resolving conflicts in healthcare?

Options:
  a. Ignoring the issue
  b. Seeking legal intervention
✓ c. Assertiveness and mutual respect
  d. Blaming others
  e. Withdrawing from the situation

Explanation:
A collaborative approach involving assertiveness and mutual respect is considered the most effective method for conflict resolution.

================================================================================
Question 1339 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 46-year-old female presents to her family physician with the complaint of double vision. Physical examination reveals ptosis. Over the next 6 months, she experiences recurrent symptoms including muscle weakness. Her symptoms abate with a trial of cholinesterase inhibitor. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  a. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  b. Duchenne's muscular dystrophy
✓ c. Myasthenia gravis
  d. Eaton-Lambert syndrome
  e. Guillain-Barré syndrome

Explanation:
The clinical presentation of diplopia, ptosis, and muscle weakness that improves with a cholinesterase inhibitor is diagnostic of Myasthenia Gravis.

================================================================================
Question 1340 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
An 83-year-old male has developed progressively worsening memory loss, impaired language function, and altered social skills over the past 4 years. A CT scan of the head revealed no anatomic abnormalities. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
  a. Parkinson's disease
✓ b. Alzheimer's dementia
  c. Cerebral infarct involving the left middle cerebral artery distribution
  d. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  e. Multiple sclerosis

Explanation:
Progressive memory loss and cognitive decline in an elderly patient with a normal CT scan (ruling out vascular causes or tumors) is most likely Alzheimer's Dementia.

================================================================================
Question 1341 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is NOT considered a potential complication of multiple sclerosis?

Options:
  a. Paralysis
✓ b. Epilepsy
  c. Cognitive impairment
  d. Urinary incontinence
  e. Loss of vision

Explanation:
While seizures can occur in MS, they are relatively rare compared to the other options (paralysis, cognitive impairment, incontinence, vision loss), which are common and direct consequences of demyelination.

================================================================================
Question 1342 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which imaging technique is commonly used to diagnose multiple sclerosis?

Options:
  a. Positron emission tomography (PET)
✓ b. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
  c. Computed tomography (CT)
  d. Electroencephalogram (EEG)
  e. Skull X-ray

Explanation:
MRI is the gold standard imaging modality for diagnosing Multiple Sclerosis, allowing visualization of demyelinated plaques.

================================================================================
Question 1343 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old female patient presented with sudden onset of bilateral lower limb weakness. She also gives a history of blindness a year ago which settled on its own. On examination, tone is increased, reflexes are brisk, and plantars are upgoing. Fundoscopy shows optic atrophy. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Options:
  a. Caries spine
✓ b. Multiple sclerosis
  c. Guillain-Barre Syndrome
  d. Cauda Equina Syndrome
  e. Cervical Spondylosis

Explanation:
The history of transient blindness (optic neuritis) followed by spinal cord involvement (paraparesis with UMN signs) indicates lesions separated in time and space, characteristic of Multiple Sclerosis.

================================================================================
Question 1344 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset of worsening paraplegia. He gives a history of fever and cough for the past three months. On examination, power is 3/5 in bilateral lower limbs, tone is increased bilaterally, reflexes are brisk, and plantars are bilateral upgoing. Upper limbs are normal on examination. What investigation will you order to confirm the diagnosis?

Options:
  a. CT Brain
  b. Lumbar Puncture
✓ c. MRI Thoracic Spine
  d. Nerve Conduction Studies
  e. MRI Lumbosacral Spine

Explanation:
The patient likely has Pott's disease (TB spine) causing cord compression (paraplegia with UMN signs). The lesion must be above the lumbar region (UMN signs), likely thoracic. MRI Thoracic Spine is the investigation of choice.

================================================================================
Question 1345 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 25-year-old female presents with weakness of lower limbs for the past four months. She also complains of double vision in the evenings. She is completely fine when she wakes up in the morning. The weakness and diplopia worsen as the day passes. On examination, power is 3/5 in both lower limbs, tone and reflexes are normal, and plantars are down going. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ a. Myasthenia Gravis
  b. Multiple Sclerosis
  c. Guillain-Barre Syndrome
  d. Cauda Equina Syndrome
  e. Cervical Spondylosis

Explanation:
Fatigable weakness (worse in evenings, better in mornings) involving ocular muscles (diplopia) and limbs is the hallmark of Myasthenia Gravis.

================================================================================
Question 1346 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Which of the following is NOT a potential complication of epilepsy?

Options:
  a. Memory loss
  b. Depression
✓ c. Hypertension
  d. Sudden unexpected death in epilepsy
  e. Fractures

Explanation:
Hypertension is not a direct complication of epilepsy, whereas memory loss, depression, SUDEP, and fractures (from falls) are known complications.

================================================================================
Question 1347 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 74-year-old male patient presented with loss of balance since 1 year. He also complains of increased forgetfulness and urinary incontinence. What is the likely diagnosis?

Options:
  a. Alzheimer's Disease
  b. Ischemic Stroke
  c. Senile Dementia
  d. Vascular Dementia
✓ e. Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus

Explanation:
The classic triad of gait disturbance (loss of balance), dementia (forgetfulness), and urinary incontinence ('Wet, Wobbly, Wacky') is diagnostic of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus.

================================================================================
Question 1348 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 35-year-old male presents with sudden onset of weakness of lower limbs starting from the foot and ascending upwards. He also gives a history of diarrhea a few days ago. On examination, power in the lower limbs is 2/5. Ankle and knee jerks are absent, and plantars are mute. What is the likely diagnosis?

Options:
✓ a. Guillain-Barre Syndrome
  b. Transverse Myelitis
  c. Tuberculous Spine
  d. Brain Tumor
  e. Cauda Equina Syndrome

Explanation:
Ascending paralysis with areflexia (LMN signs) following a GI infection is characteristic of Guillain-Barré Syndrome.

================================================================================
Question 1349 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
Immediately after the surgery, the patient is usually shifted to

Options:
  a. CCU
  b. PACU
  c. ICU
  d. HDU
✓ e. Recovery Room

Explanation:
Post-surgery, patients are routinely transferred to the Recovery Room (or Post-Anesthesia Care Unit - PACU) for monitoring.

================================================================================
Question 1350 (WMC - 2024)
================================================================================

Question:
A 45-year-old woman is rushed to the emergency room following an automobile accident. Ten hours after admission, the patient complains of a severe headache and blurred vision. An X-ray film of the cranium shows a fracture of the temporal parietal bone. Despite emergency craniotomy, the patient dies. Which of the following pathologic findings would be expected at autopsy?

Options:
✓ a. Epidural hematoma
  b. Intracerebral hemorrhage
  c. Intraventricular hemorrhage
  d. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  e. Subdural hematoma

Explanation:
A temporal bone fracture often tears the middle meningeal artery, leading to an Epidural Hematoma, which typically presents with a lucid interval followed by rapid deterioration.
